neighborhoods.name: Place de l'Hôtel de Ville
neighborhoods.character: Magnificent main square and historic heart of Le Havre, featuring UNESCO World Heritage architecture and the iconic City Hall
neighborhoods.location: Central Le Havre, the main square and surrounding area
neighborhoods.history: The heart of Le Havre since the post-war reconstruction, this elegant square is surrounded by stunning buildings designed by Auguste Perret, including the magnificent City Hall. It's the perfect starting point for exploring Le Havre's unique architectural heritage and maritime setting.

practical_info.getting_there: Central location, accessible by tram and bus

neighborhoods.appeal: High - Popular with tourists, locals, and those seeking cultural experiences

attractions: Place de l'Hôtel de Ville Square

neighborhoods.tips: Visit during the day for the best light on the UNESCO World Heritage buildings. The area is pedestrian-friendly and perfect for exploring Le Havre's unique post-war architectural heritage.

neighborhoods.name: Historic Center (Vieille Ville)
neighborhoods.character: Historic heart of Le Havre with surviving pre-war buildings, medieval architecture, and traditional Norman character
neighborhoods.location: Central Le Havre, the old town area
neighborhoods.history: The historic core of Le Havre featuring surviving buildings from before World War II, including the Cathédrale Notre-Dame. This area showcases the city's pre-war heritage and traditional Norman architecture, offering a contrast to the modernist reconstruction.

practical_info.getting_there: Central location, accessible by tram and walking

neighborhoods.appeal: High - Essential for understanding Le Havre's history and culture
neighborhoods.tips: Visit early morning to avoid crowds and get the best photos. This area offers a glimpse into Le Havre's pre-war character and traditional Norman heritage.

neighborhoods.name: Les Halles Centrales
neighborhoods.character: Authentic local market area with traditional Norman atmosphere and fresh seafood
neighborhoods.location: Central Le Havre, near the historic center
neighborhoods.history: Traditional covered market area offering authentic local experience with traditional Norman products, fresh seafood, and regional specialties. The market has served as the city's main food market for decades, surrounded by historic buildings and a vibrant atmosphere.

practical_info.getting_there: Walking distance from center, accessible by tram
practical_info.safety: Safe during market hours, be aware of crowds

neighborhoods.appeal: Medium-High - Great for experiencing local culture and finding fresh food
neighborhoods.tips: Visit early morning for the freshest seafood and most authentic experience. Bring cash for purchases. Be respectful when taking photos of vendors and their goods.

neighborhoods.name: Rue de Paris
neighborhoods.character: Elegant historic street lined with beautiful buildings, boutique shops, and traditional restaurants
neighborhoods.location: Central Le Havre, connecting Place de l'Hôtel de Ville to the historic center
neighborhoods.history: One of Le Havre's most beautiful historic streets, lined with elegant buildings, boutique shops, and traditional restaurants. The street showcases Norman architecture and is perfect for shopping, dining, and admiring the city's architectural heritage.

practical_info.best_time_to_visit: Daytime for shopping, evening for dining
practical_info.getting_there: Central location, walking distance from main attractions

neighborhoods.appeal: High - Excellent for shopping, dining, and architecture appreciation
neighborhoods.tips: This area is perfect for leisurely exploration. Take time to admire the architectural details of the historic buildings. Many shops and restaurants are closed on Sundays.

neighborhoods.name: Port Area
neighborhoods.character: Historic port area with maritime heritage, working docks, and spectacular harbor views
neighborhoods.location: Western edge of the city, along the English Channel
neighborhoods.history: The historic port of Le Havre, one of France's largest and busiest ports, offering fascinating views of massive cargo ships, container terminals, and maritime activity. The port area showcases Le Havre's economic importance and maritime heritage.

practical_info.getting_there: Walking distance from center, accessible by tram

neighborhoods.appeal: High - Essential for understanding Le Havre's maritime character
neighborhoods.tips: Visit during clear weather for the best harbor views. Respect port security zones. Best viewed from designated observation points. Perfect for maritime photography.

neighborhoods.name: Sainte-Adresse
neighborhoods.character: Elegant seaside district with Belle Époque architecture, beautiful beaches, and panoramic views
neighborhoods.location: North of the city center, along the coast
neighborhoods.history: A historic seaside resort area known for its Belle Époque architecture, beautiful beaches, and panoramic views of the English Channel. The area features elegant villas, historic hotels, and a sophisticated atmosphere that attracted artists and wealthy visitors in the 19th century.

practical_info.getting_there: Tram connections, walking distance from center

neighborhoods.appeal: High - Great for seaside relaxation, architecture, and coastal views
neighborhoods.tips: Visit during good weather for the best coastal views. The area is perfect for seaside walks and admiring the elegant Belle Époque architecture. Great for sunset photography.

neighborhoods.name: Saint-Vincent
neighborhoods.character: University district with modern architecture, student life, and cultural venues
neighborhoods.location: East of the city center, near the university
neighborhoods.history: A modern district developed around the University of Le Havre, featuring contemporary architecture, student housing, cultural venues, and a vibrant atmosphere. The area is known for its youthful energy and modern amenities.

practical_info.getting_there: Tram connections, walking distance from center

neighborhoods.appeal: Medium-High - Great for modern culture, student life, and contemporary architecture
neighborhoods.tips: Visit during the academic year to experience the vibrant student atmosphere. The area offers a contrast to the historic center with its modern architecture and contemporary culture.
